posts.post_content:
I passed this in a draft. It came back to me with one card left in the pack, so I took it.  
I was thinking, "what kind of deck would I ever put this in?"  
Then somebody said, "it's the best blue reanimation target of all freakin' time stupid!"  
  
And then I was enlightened. With a blue/ black reanimanator, or even a mono-block reanimator, this is a damn, damn fine target. I don't think it's as good as Iona, but it's close.

posts.post_content: Jin-Gitaxis is the God of card advantage. He is the essence of having more cards than your opponent. Every card that makes your opponent discard, every card that makes you draw- they all pray to him. Even if he isn't playable or whatever. Consecrated sphinx is pretty high on the long-term card advantage scale, but if he lives for even until their end step he's already by far the best card advantage possible.

posts.post_content:
Turn One: Play a [Swamp](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Swamp), followed by a [Dark Ritual](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Dark Ritual). Then play [Entomb](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Entomb), search for this guy, and finish up with [Exhume](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Exhume) to put him in play.  
Turn Two: There probably won't be a turn two, because unless your opponents can kill him with one mana on their first turn, they might as well forfeit.  
  
Sure, it would only work in casual and would require the perfect opening draw, but it would be awesome to pull it off. And then you could switch to a different deck for the next game--otherwise, your friends will probably not be your friends anymore.
posts.html:

Sure, it would only work in casual and would require the perfect opening draw, but it would be awesome to pull it off. And then you could switch to a different deck for the next game--otherwise, your friends will probably not be your friends anymore.

posts.post_content:
I really want to play this card. I really, really do. But at 10 mana, I just can't bring myself to. At the 10 mana mark you really want to be playing cards that put you into pole position, such as Blightsteel Colossus, Kozilek and Ulamog (all around 10 mana). This card offers insane, insane card advantage (and also forces you to include at least one Eldrazi in your deck for discard-recycling purposes), but if you're hard casting him, in a control deck (where he's best suited) you want an actual finisher at 10 mana, if you even go that high. To put it into context, at 6 mana Consecrated Sphinx will get you at least a 3-for-1 if it isn't killed before your opponents draw step, beats for almost as much as this guy, has a bigger rear end AND evasion, and doesn't require constantly hitting land drops.  
  
Of course, there's the other method of getting him out - cheating him out, via something like Summoning Trap. But that's brings about the question again: if you're going to cheat out somethin... [(see all)](javascript:void(0);)

posts.post_content:
Obviously not made for standard, but for reanimation EDH decks, and made well (remember that Kozilek, Ulamog and Emrakul don't like to be in graveyards, but this does). Expect unlimited hate from all other players, like no other card.
  
Pretty lame flavour text though, just more phyrexian propaganda, with something this epic, it should have been something like "Their minds shall be torn apart, and in their fleshy ignorance they shall know the true power of phyrexian dominance as my eternal brilliance brings them to their knees!".

Posted By: Sironos (5/3/2011 3:43:36 PM)
Rating:

posts.post_content:
Absolutely the best card I have seen yet.  
  
Threw him in my deck with my [Lighthouse Chronologist](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Lighthouse Chronologist), [Rite of Replication](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Rite of Replication), [High Tide](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=High Tide), [Reminisce](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Reminisce), and [Time Stop](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Time Stop).  
  
Yes, that's right...  
  
To one of your turns I take seven, and each seven-turn cycle takes me through all my spells and puts it back for the next cycle. Meanwhile, you have nothing to use against me, and even if you did, your turn ends as soon as I tell it to. And, yes, I take *seven more*.  
  
This is why I play blue. 5/5
posts.html:

This is why I play blue. 5/5

Posted By: Justice1337 (9/15/2011 2:47:52 PM)
Rating:

posts.post_content:
This card represents everything blue is supposed to be: a thirst for knowledge so obsessive-compulsive you could drown in it if you're not careful.  
  
A sadistic way to win with this card that I really prefer is using [Zedruu the Greathearted](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Zedruu the Greathearted) or some similar donate effect to donate Jin-Gitaxias (and however many [Thought Reflection](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Thought Reflection)s you've decided to put into play) and watch your opponent mill himself via card draw. Using Zedruu's card draw plus [Solitary Confinement](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Solitary Confinement), your opponent can't really utilize the benefits you're giving him. Your pick of a [Jester's Cap](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Jester's Cap) type effect can be used beforehand to remove any possible graveyard recycling.  
  
Terribly inefficient way to do things, really, but it's an amazing 'win more' feeling if you can pull it off.
posts.html:
This card represents everything blue is supposed to be: a thirst for knowledge so obsessive-compulsive you could drown in it if you're not careful.

A sadistic way to win with this card that I really prefer is using Zedruu the Greathearted or some similar donate effect to donate Jin-Gitaxias (and however many Thought Reflections you've decided to put into play) and watch your opponent mill himself via card draw. Using Zedruu's card draw plus Solitary Confinement, your opponent can't really utilize the benefits you're giving him. Your pick of a Jester's Cap type effect can be used beforehand to remove any possible graveyard recycling.

Terribly inefficient way to do things, really, but it's an amazing 'win more' feeling if you can pull it off.

posts.post_content:
T1: [Quest for Ancient Secrets](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Quest for Ancient Secrets)  
T2: [Jace's Erasure](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Jace's Erasure)  
T3: [Swiftfoot Boots](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Swiftfoot Boots)  
T4: [Quicksilver Amulet](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Quicksilver Amulet)  
T5: Tap 4 and Quicksilver Amulet for [Jin-Gitaxias, Core Augur](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Jin-Gitaxias, Core Augur) and Tap 1 to equip Swiftfoot Boots to Jin-Gitaxias  
T6 and on: Watch as opponent cries and can't do anything. They mill 1 Card during your UUD, and 7 Cards at your End Phase. When you're library shrinks too much, use Quest for Ancient Secrets. Have a few Cancels or Mana Leaks, etc to stop you're opponent's 1 single card from ruining your strategy.

posts.post_content:
i'm very mixed about this guy; his third ability is absolutely amazing, but i don't find his first two to be of much use, and his cmc is hilariously high.  
my idealized version of this card is:   
8 cmc  
same third ability  
2/6 p/t  
  
you can get him out a a little earlier, and the higher toughness means he stays around longer  
  
still pretty good  
  
4/5
